results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 14 contains footage of the royal tour visiting Warragul and the Latrobe Valley, followed by a visit to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research.

Detailed Description Reel 14:

Opens with Title “Warragul”, followed by footage of Queen and Duke exiting railway station (?) and at 00:00:20:00 entering car. 00:00:30:00 flag-waving crowd of children, Queen and Duke mounting dais and waving to crowd. 00:00:43:00 Queen making speech. 00:00:55:00 child presents flowers. 00:01:09:00 locals presented. 00:01:38:00 footage is of crowd along tracks from moving train. 00:01:45:00 footage is of train itself moving along tracks and a distance shot as train moves through very flat grasslands. 00:02:04:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the University of Melbourne”, followed by very brief footage of flag flying over (presumably) a Melbourne University building. 00:02:17:00 Title “Visit of His Royal Highness to the Walter and Eliza Hall Institute of Medical Research”, followed by shots of the Institute buildings at Royal Melbourne Hospital. 00:03:12:00 the Duke arrives in open car, and greets waiting crowd and children before entering building, where we see some Institute equipment and staff at work. More footage of crowd outside. 00:03:59:00 the Duke exits, moves to car and is driven away.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 39]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows the Gadsdens gathering at Surfers Paradise in Queensland, for Easter in 1987. We see swimming and general beach activity, surfing and paddling in the waves. There is an Easter egg hunt in the holiday house yard and we also see the a barbeque on a 1970s three-legged hotplate and beers being drunk from ‘stubby holders’.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:07:03:00 cooking on a 1970s three-legged barbeque

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is comprised of two parts. Firstly, travelling on a road tour through South Gippsland from Wilson’s Promontory to Walhalla, Kenneth shows his appreciation of the Australian countryside as he shows the landscape, forests, shorelines and features around him. At times. Kenneth himself appears in the reel on the other side of camera. When at Wilson’s Promontary the footage indicates the style of camping at the time: individual cabins alongside shared facilities likely to have included bathrooms, kitchen and laundry and recreation rooms. Kenneth also shows the old goldtown of Walhalla with its deserted atmosphere. The last part of the reel shows a waterski regatta and speed boats on Albert Park Lake in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:27:00 distant views and roads on the way though what we will come to know is Gippsland.

00:00:32:00 ‘Wilson’s Promontory’ sign, posted alongside the Darby Bridge, its sign and Bob Wootton standing on the bridge.

00:00:38:00 Kenneth Rankine himself looking out over the Darby River.

00:00:45:00 to 00:01:40:00 views of the sea over low lying hills followed by shots of teatree, country roads leading down to the sea, views of the coastline, rocky hills and flower shots.

00:01:42:00 ‘Tidal River’ camping grounds. Just before departing the Prom, there is a lovely view of what appears to be Norman Bay near Tidal River.

00:02:04:00 a sign for ‘Port Welshpool’ followed by views of an estuary at low tide, several piers and fishing boats.

00:02:36:00 a fisherman appears (as indicated by thigh high galoshes) walking along a pier and chatting to Bob Wootton.

00:03:01:00 a sign for the ‘Balook Private Hotel Excellent Accommodation’.

00:03:28:00 after more hillsides and views we see a sign for ‘Bulga Park Shire of Alberton’ (which existed 1855 to 1994; currently Shire of Wellington).

00:04:28:00 sign for Tarra Valley Park appears. In this footage Kenneth has gone to some trouble to capture the Parks, framing his shots of waterfalls, ferns and trees through bracken fronds, branches or rope walks to create a lush feel.

00:06:32 the Corrigan Suspension (walk) Bridge. Shortly after, we are looking down on the Thomson River. Kenneth includes several shots of bridges including the first from which he takes footage of the river below.

00:07:02:00 perhaps foot bridge evident by the scratched initials on the railing. Rail and road bridges are shot from different angles from 00:06:48 to 00:07:02:00.

00:07:10:00 Walhalla Post Office; some deserted and derelict buildings, a shop sign for ‘Agent of the State Savings Bank Guaranteed by the Government of Victoria’ on the door of a derelict Teashop, the Walhalla Station sign on a building which houses old carts with a shot of ‘1903’ on one of the carts, elaborate stone walls.

00:08:11:00 a working timber mill. There are more shots of overgrown brick remnants of buildings in the steep hillsides, rail tracks and old cars.

00:08:41:00 Bob Wootton works a rail lever to move the old tracks. Kenneth has taken views of the town that reflect the almost abandoned state of Walhalla at the time, following the end of the gold mining boom and after the ‘Black Friday’ bushfires that ravaged the State in 1939.

00:08:54:00 program for the ‘A Speedboat and Water - Ski Regatta assisted by the Sirocco Cherokee and Yarrawonga Water Ski Clubs’, held at Albert Park Lake (Melbourne) in 1956. Footage of speedboat racing on the lake follows.

00:10:21:00 a helicopter is filmed flying and hovering overhead.

00:10:30:00 men water skiing; good examples of male swimming trunks. A largish crowd of onlookers and several lakeside buildings.

00:11:37:00 ski jumps.

00:12:40:00 footage of an early display of kitesurfing.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 58]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures Gadsden family gatherings at the poolside and for a Christmas party at their Toorak, Melbourne home in the 1970s.

There are some great examples of 1970s style fashion trends and hair styles across the generations and a view into the family’s life at home, such as enjoying their backyard pool. Unusually, filmmaker Ron himself is filmed handing out the presents at the Christmas party.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 scenes of family floating the pool in the family garden
00:00:40:00 an array of fashion of the era
00:00:58:00 a beer moment
00:01:28:00 Ron Gadsden in a 1970s style cravat
00:02:46:00 Ron distributes Christmas presents
00:03:41:00 Jess Gadsden in the pool

description_for_label:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film captures Gadsden family gatherings at the poolside and for a Christmas party at their Toorak, Melbourne home in the 1970s.

There are some great examples of 1970s style fashion trends and hair styles across the generations and a view into the family’s life at home, such as enjoying their backyard pool. Unusually, filmmaker Ron himself is filmed handing out the presents at the Christmas party.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:15:00 scenes of family floating the pool in the family garden
00:00:40:00 an array of fashion of the era
00:00:58:00 a beer moment
00:01:28:00 Ron Gadsden in a 1970s style cravat
00:02:46:00 Ron distributes Christmas presents
00:03:41:00 Jess Gadsden in the pool

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

In Reel 9 we see the Royal tour in the Victorian regional town of Hamilton, then attending a special race meeting at Flemington Racecourse.

Detailed Description Reel 9:

Starts with Title “Visit to Hamilton: Departure from Melbourne Airport (Overseas Terminal) Friday, February, 26th. 1954.” Tarmac and crowd scenes at Essendon (Melbourne) Airport. 00:01:06:00 Queen and Duke board plane. 00:01:36:00 plane taking off. 00:01:55:00 various officials boarding another plane. 00:02:53:00 plane landing. 00:03:02:00 arrival at Hamilton, Queen and Duke exit plane, followed by crowd scenes and presentation on dais. 00:03:43:00 motorcade through Hamilton (local streets and buildings) followed by greetings and crowd scenes at an official reception (at what appears to be a local sports ground). 00:04:56:00 Title “Flemington Race Meeting Saturday, February, 27th. 1954.” followed by shot of betting windows at Flemington, crowd scenes, people placing bets, close-ups of fashions and millinery styles. 00:05:35:00 Queen and Duke in open car, with mounted police. 00:05:59:00 greetings from VRC officials 00:07:15:00 mounting yard. 00:07:26:00 Title “Newmarket Handicap”, followed by interspersed scenes of crowd and horse-race. 00:08:01:00 Queen leaves stand and crowds begin to disperse.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel opens with the title ‘Surfers Paradise May 1975’ written in the sand between waves. The subtitle ‘Passing Parade’ shows the filmmakers intention: life on the beach on the Gold Coast at the time. The reel begins with early morning scenes of both the beach and the duplex holiday house situated right on the sand. We see lots of surfing – board surfing, body surfing and a longboard with paddles. We also see a large jellyfish in the sand, frisbee playing, strolling along the sand in 1970s fashion flares, Gadsdens running in a group along the beach, family members fishing, a commercial fishing boat in the waves, knitting on a towel on sand, sitting on the house balcony with drinks, a barbeque on the rooftop and views along the coastline.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:56:00 ice cream cart on the beach
00:13:14:00 the filmmaker himself enjoying a XXXX beer while smiling for the camera
00:13:53:00 mid-rise apartment blocks along the coast more sparsely spaced than now

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 8 captures the Queen opening the Victorian State Parliament, and the Queen and Duke meeting with Australian armed forces veterans at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG).

Detailed Description Reel 8:

Opens with Title “Opening of Parliament: Thursday, 25th. February, 1954.” followed by shots of Government House and gardens. 00:00:35:00 Queen (in state dress) and Duke exit and get into open car, which leaves Government House and moves along St. Kilda Road and city streets with crowd shots on the way. 00:02:06:00 inside State Parliament. 00:02:19:00 leaving State Parliament through crowds and back into car. 00:03:19:00 Title “Assembly of Ex-Servicemen’s and Women’s Organisations, Junior Legatees and War Widows. Melbourne Cricket Ground.” 00:03:30:00 marching military bands, veterans in wheelchairs, and arrival of Queen and Duke in open car, which drives around perimeter then to centre of ground. 00:05:06:00 Philip makes speech from dais. 00:05:20:00 children present flowers. 00:05:58:00 footage of various groups marching. 00:07:00:00 Queen and Duke leave dais and speak with veterans. 00:07:58 to end - Queen and Duke re-enter open car and leave Melbourne Cricket Ground.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film opens with a ‘red rattler’ train at Lilydale station, in Victoria. It is Christmas Day in 1970 and the filmmaker’s daughter Elenor Peach and her husband Ron are boarding the train. The ‘red rattler’ was the name affectionally given to the ‘Tait carriage’ wooden-bodied electric trains that ran in metropolitan Melbourne, Victoria, from 1919 to the early 1980s (named after the then Commissioner of Railways Sir Thomas Tait).

Most of the film captures a holiday around regional Victoria and include great examples of holiday life in the 1970s, such as men’s and women’s bathing suits, sunglasses, sunhats, beach umbrellas, surfing, picnics and station-wagon cars for travelling and camping at a creek among Australian tea trees.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a wonderful close-up of a ‘red rattler’ train pulled up at a station
00:00:25:00 a group of holiday makers sitting on camp chairs next to a creek
00:00:35:00 collecting water from the creek
00:00:57:00 close-ups of the holiday makers including a wonderful example of a handmade 1960s/1970s gingham smocking hat
00:01:50:00 a young woman in a bikini bathing suit and bathing cap enters the fast running creek water
00:02:12:00 swimming and a close-up of the 1960s/1970s rubber bathing cap which is covered in pink flowers
00:02:18:00 looking through insect netting to a man holding a baby (which lends an interesting effect)
00:02:45:00 young men in ‘cut off shorts’ fixing a Holden model car
00:02:53:00 lovely intergenerational picture of a very young baby held by an elderly age man who is wearing braces (rather than a belt)for his trousers of an earlier era
00:03:17:00 swimming along the creek and sitting on the bank
00:04:22:00 focus on a full head of hair ‘curlers’ as used at the time
00:04:29:00 views of rocky terrain and bush and a woman with a camera takes a photo of the filmmaker
00:05:45:00 rock climbing and views the Grampians mountain range (Geriwerd, Gariwerd) in Western Victoria
00:08:19:00 views of the township of Stawell in regional Victoria
00:08:58:00 title ‘Seascape’ written in sand followed by views of the sea and coastline, likely to be around the coastal town of Lorne in Victoria
00:09:55:00 surfboards strapped to a van followed by golfing on a cliff overlooking the sea
00:10:05:00 views of surfers in the water, a swimmer walking from the sea to her towel and the group of holiday makers sitting on the sand under a beach umbrella
00:10:46:00 taking a shot through a camera on a tripod on the sand
00:11:38:00 colourful beach umbrellas and bathers with a car of the era in the background
00:12:37:00 a roadside picnic
00:12:57:00 wonderful example of decorative sunglasses of the era
00:13:17:00 title ‘The End’ written in the sand

This film opens with a ‘red rattler’ train at Lilydale station, in Victoria. It is Christmas Day in 1970 and the filmmaker’s daughter Elenor Peach and her husband Ron are boarding the train. The ‘red rattler’ was the name affectionally given to the ‘Tait carriage’ wooden-bodied electric trains that ran in metropolitan Melbourne, Victoria, from 1919 to the early 1980s (named after the then Commissioner of Railways Sir Thomas Tait).

Most of the film captures a holiday around regional Victoria and include great examples of holiday life in the 1970s, such as men’s and women’s bathing suits, sunglasses, sunhats, beach umbrellas, surfing, picnics and station-wagon cars for travelling and camping at a creek among Australian tea trees.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a wonderful close-up of a ‘red rattler’ train pulled up at a station
00:00:25:00 a group of holiday makers sitting on camp chairs next to a creek
00:00:35:00 collecting water from the creek
00:00:57:00 close-ups of the holiday makers including a wonderful example of a handmade 1960s/1970s gingham smocking hat
00:01:50:00 a young woman in a bikini bathing suit and bathing cap enters the fast running creek water
00:02:12:00 swimming and a close-up of the 1960s/1970s rubber bathing cap which is covered in pink flowers
00:02:18:00 looking through insect netting to a man holding a baby (which lends an interesting effect)
00:02:45:00 young men in ‘cut off shorts’ fixing a Holden model car
00:02:53:00 lovely intergenerational picture of a very young baby held by an elderly age man who is wearing braces (rather than a belt)for his trousers of an earlier era
00:03:17:00 swimming along the creek and sitting on the bank
00:04:22:00 focus on a full head of hair ‘curlers’ as used at the time
00:04:29:00 views of rocky terrain and bush and a woman with a camera takes a photo of the filmmaker
00:05:45:00 rock climbing and views the Grampians mountain range (Geriwerd, Gariwerd) in Western Victoria
00:08:19:00 views of the township of Stawell in regional Victoria
00:08:58:00 title ‘Seascape’ written in sand followed by views of the sea and coastline, likely to be around the coastal town of Lorne in Victoria
00:09:55:00 surfboards strapped to a van followed by golfing on a cliff overlooking the sea
00:10:05:00 views of surfers in the water, a swimmer walking from the sea to her towel and the group of holiday makers sitting on the sand under a beach umbrella
00:10:46:00 taking a shot through a camera on a tripod on the sand
00:11:38:00 colourful beach umbrellas and bathers with a car of the era in the background
00:12:37:00 a roadside picnic
00:12:57:00 wonderful example of decorative sunglasses of the era
00:13:17:00 title ‘The End’ written in the sand

group.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection]
group.material_description:
5 x 400ft 9.5mm B&W silent home movies
7 x 8mm reels (4 x 100ft, 2 x 400ft)

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 133]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film is in two parts. The first shows downhill skiing at Perisher, a large ski resort in the Snowy Mountains of New South Wales. The second, a sports day at ‘Glamorgan’ kindergarten, now the Melbourne ‘prep’ campus of Geelong Grammar.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:00 skiing downhill past camera
00:01:22 skier walking cross country, building in background
00:01:29 child skiing
00:01:43 close up footage of ski lodge verandah
00:01:50 school boys lining up
00:02:03 running and wheelbarrow races on grass
00:02:54 high jump over bar on wooden blocks
00:03:13 closeup female teacher
00:03:17 bean bag race
00:03:48 running race with midway stop to put on painting smock
00:04:21 women and school girls (in hats) watch sports – hats and sunglasses
00:04:29 timekeepers desk

results.title: Flash Back: ACMI Collections Mash-up White Night 2017
results.brief_description:
‘Flash Back’, an archival mashup of films and footage from the 1940s through to the ‘80s celebrating the changing face of Australian youth identity and culture.

From rebel youth of the ‘50s, to the ‘70s counter culture revolution and the punk attitudes of the ‘80s, ‘Flash Back’ explores the changing decades through diverse subcultures and the music, fashions and cultural preoccupations that shaped them.

Image: ‘Sharpies: A Gathering’, courtesy Greg Macainsh

Our sincere thanks to filmmakers, musicians and donors for material used in this work. Full details in credits. Edited by ACMI’s Sam Mapplebeck.
